# PR Summary

Make the Linux CI build once and then run the tests on 4 different machines, by tag.

## PR Context

Running in parallel allows us to run all tests in about the same amount of clock time

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
Looks great!

Unelevated tests on all platforms take about 13-14 minutes. Can we split them and run on 2-3 VMs?

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: @iSazonov 	We can split them up by folder or another tag.  Folder would be easier.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: We also need to remove the [feature] tag code.  It causes problems and isn't needed after this PR.  I'll do it in another PR...

comments.author: RDIL
comments.body: @travisez13 I’ll take care of it after this is merged.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
>  Folder would be easier.

It seems we need to put the list in a config file to load-balance VMs.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body: @iSazonov 	That might work... the script would need to see if any folders had been added and run those on some machine designated as a primary machine

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: Interesting, can these machines interact so as to receive a test batch from a controller VM and return a report? This would solve the load-balancing problem. And we could use this for remoting tests.

comments.author: TravisEz13
comments.body:
@iSazonov 	Interactions between the machines may work sometimes but not consistently.  The machines are only given private IP Addresses and are not guaranteed to be on the same subnet.  I don't think we need that complexity.  It's not needed to create a solution.  The added complexity would add failure cases.

A simpler solution does mean that we would need to manually rebalance occasionally, but I don't think that is a problem.
